thread.title: These are the attorneys fighting for and against Trump travel ban
thread.title_full: These are the attorneys fighting for and against Trump travel ban

author: Jaweed Kaleem
title: These are the attorneys fighting for and against Trump travel ban
text:
Live updates: 9th Circuit Court of Appeals to hear arguments over restoring Trump's travel ban   
What to expect today in the legal fight over President Trump's order to block all refugees from around the world and immigrants from seven predominantly Muslim countries: There has been a flurry of lawsuits as the appeals court decides whether Trump's immigration ban will be enforced. It currently is not. The law backs a president's power on immigration. Here's where the travel ban differs. Homeland Security secretary: The chaotic rollout of Trump's travel ban is "all on me." Trump vows to keep fighting for 'common sense' travel ban The most important lawsuits to watch Read Trump's executive order and legal filings for and against the travel ban Background Feb. 7, 2017, 3:00 p.m. These are the attorneys fighting for and against Trump's travel ban Jaweed Kaleem Solicitor General Noah Purcell (C) and Washington state Attorney General Bob Ferguson (R) speak at a press conference outside U.S. District Court, Western Washington, on February 3, 2017 in Seattle. (Karen Ducey / Getty Images) 
The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals has released the names of the attorneys who will argue for and against Trump's travel ban Tuesday. 
Noah G. Purcell, the Washington State solicitor general, will represent the states of Washington and Minnesota. Those states filed the lawsuit that resulted in a federal district judge's decision in Seattle Friday to halt Trump's executive order nationwide. 
Washington State Attorney General Bob Ferguson said it was Purcell's idea to enlist major tech companies in the state to file briefs supporting the state's suit against Trump's executive order. 
Purcell was a Supreme Court clerk for now-retired Justice David Souter. 
August E. Flentje, a career trial attorney in the Department of Justice's civil division, will represent the Trump administration. 
In his 19 years in the department, nearly all in the civil division, Flentje has worked under every president since Bill Clinton. He was part of a team that received an an award from former Attorney General Eric Holder in 2013 for "extraordinary work" in the legal maneuvering around the Obama administration's decision to support same-sex marriage in defiance of the Defense of Marriage Act passed by Congress. 
In a 100-plus page legal brief to the appeals court, the White House was first represented by Acting Solicitor General Noel Francisco and Acting Associate Attorney General Chad Readler. They removed their names from the most recent court briefing after their former employer, legal firm Jones Day, filed an amicus brief regarding the travel ban. 
Each side was to be allotted 30 minutes to present oral arguments, including time for questions from the judges. Latest updates
